metadata.case_name: Official Liquidators of U. P. Union Bank Ltd. v. Respondent Landlord

facts.text: U. P. Union Bank Ltd. was tenant of building in Agra at monthly rental of Rs. 325 and Rs. 10 municipal taxes.
Bank defaulted in paying rent; respondent filed Suit No. 810 of 1949 in Court of Munsiff Agra for rent for three months and obtained attachment before judgment on movable property.
Munsiff decreed suit on December 2, 1949, confirming attachment.
On petition dated September 13, 1949, High Court ordered winding up of Bank and appointed appellants as liquidators.
Employees of Bank vacated premises on September 10, 1949.
Attached property stored by Commissioner in banking hall, premises sealed; part occupied by trespassers.
Official Liquidators called upon respondent to take possession, but respondent declined unless vacant possession of entire premises given.
On November 30, 1950, respondent applied to High Court for permission to file suit for ejectment and arrears of rent since September 30, 1949.
Mootham J. on August 30, 1951, held respondent entitled to recover rent at Rs. 325 per mensem from October 1, 1949, up to date Official Liquidators give possession terminating tenancy.
Official Liquidators appealed (Special Appeal No. 17 of 1952).
On April 23, 1953, respondent applied for certificate of non-satisfaction; Joint Registrar issued certificate and directed transmission for execution.
Execution in Civil Judge Allahabad; attachment of Rs. 12,000 in Allahabad Bank to credit of Official Liquidators.
Official Liquidators applied to High Court; Brij Mohan Lall J. held execution void without sanction under ss. 171, 232 Companies Act, recalled certificate.
Respondent special appeal No. 20 of 1954; Appeals 17/1952 and 20/1954 heard together.

High Court on April 17, 1956, dismissed Appeal 17/1952, modified Brij Mohan Lall J. order, directed Official Liquidators to pay respondent in full rent due after October 1, 1949, under proviso to r.97 Company Rules.
High Court found liquidators retained premises not for purpose of winding up but unable to dispose due to circumstances; no challenge to this finding.

legal_issues.text: Whether landlord entitled to priority payment of rent accruing post-winding up under proviso to r.97 High Court Company Rules, despite premises not used for purpose of liquidation.
Whether rent qualifies as costs and expenses of winding up under ss.193, 230 Companies Act 1913 entitling to priority.

petitioner_arguments.text: Rule 97 merely gives right to claim rent, no priority; priority only under s.230, landlord not included.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.230 Indian Companies Act 1913; r.97 High Court Company Rules

petitioner_arguments.text: Premises not used for liquidation; offered possession to landlord; High Court found no use for winding up.
English cases hold no full rent if liquidator merely abstains from disposing property.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: In re Silkstone (17 Ch.D.158); In re Oak Pits (1882 Ch.D.21); In re Levy (1919 Ch.D.416)

petitioner_arguments.text: Mootham J. order declares liability, not priority.

respondent_arguments.text: Mootham J. order entitles to full recovery from date of winding up to possession; virtually under s.45B Banking Companies Act.
Official Liquidators retained occupation, so entitled to full rent under proviso to r.97.

court_reasoning.text: Mootham J. order declares liability for rent since Oct 1,1949, no direction for payment or priority decision.
S.230 prescribes priorities; landlord rent not included. High Court cannot add via rules (s.246).
court_reasoning.key_observation: R.97 proviso affirms right to claim rent post-winding up but no priority.

court_reasoning.text: Rent priority only if costs/expenses of winding up (ss.193,230(3)); requires court order and use for liquidation purpose.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Liquidators did not use premises for winding up.

court_reasoning.text: Distinction: rent full if occupation for realization of assets; not if merely retained without use for liquidation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cited Oak Pits: no full rent if liquidator abstains from disposal.

court_reasoning.text: Liquidators could disclaim onerous covenants (s.230A) but rent ordinary debt unless costs of winding up.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court finding unchallenged: no use for winding up.

holdings.text: Proviso to r.97 does not give landlord priority for post-winding up rent; merely preserves right to claim.
Rent accruing post-winding up not entitled to priority unless part of costs/expenses of winding up and premises used for liquidation purpose.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re Silkstone and Dodworth Coal and Iron Company
precedents_cited.relevance: Liquidators not liable for rent if premises not used for liquidation.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re Oak Pits Colliery Company
precedents_cited.relevance: Landlord not entitled to full rent post-winding up if liquidator merely abstains from disposal.
Supports no liability for rent without use for liquidation.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Companies Act, 1913
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs priorities in winding up; rent not preferential unless costs of winding up.

statutes_cited.name: Companies Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: 1913 Act continues to apply to pre-1956 winding ups.

statutes_cited.name: Banking Companies Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Respondent claimed Mootham order under this for full payment.

statutes_cited.name: High Court Company Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Proviso preserves claim for rent during occupation but no priority.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, disagreeing with High Court that r.97 proviso gives landlord priority for rent; held rent ordinary debt pro rata with other creditors as premises not used for winding up purpose.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court order set aside; no priority payment to landlord.

key_quotes.text: "No authority has yet gone the length of deciding that a landlord is entitled to distrain for or be paid in full rent accruing since the commencement of the winding up, where the liquidator has done nothing except abstain from trying to get rid of the property."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle distinguishing occupation for liquidation vs. mere retention.

key_quotes.text: "The proviso merely affirms the right of the landlord to claim payment of rent accruing due since the date of winding up. It does not deal with any question of priority in payment of debts."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interpretation of r.97 proviso rejecting priority.
